expanded_description: Understanding one-sided limits and their relationship to two-sided limits, essential for analyzing function behavior at critical points.

core_concept.explanation: A two-sided limit $\lim_{x \to c} f(x)$ exists if and only if both one-sided limits exist and are equal: $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)$. One-sided limits examine function behavior from only one direction, which is crucial for piecewise functions and points of discontinuity.

image.alt: Diagram comparing one-sided and two-sided limit approaches
image.caption: Figure 1: One-sided limits approach from left ($x \to c^-$) or right ($x \to c^+$), while two-sided limits require both sides to agree.

sections.introduction: In previous sections, we examined limits where $x$ approaches $c$ from both directions simultaneously. However, some functions behave differently depending on which direction we approach from. One-sided limits allow us to analyze these cases precisely.

image.alt: Graph showing left and right approach to a point
image.caption: Figure 2: Left-hand limit approaches from values less than $c$; right-hand limit approaches from values greater than $c$.

key_concept.definition: The left-hand limit $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = L$ means $f(x)$ approaches $L$ as $x$ approaches $c$ from values less than $c$. The right-hand limit $\lim_{x \to c^+} f(x) = L$ means $f(x)$ approaches $L$ as $x$ approaches $c$ from values greater than $c$.
key_concept.context: The minus sign ($c^-$) indicates approach from the left; the plus sign ($c^+$) indicates approach from the right.

principles.statement: One-sided limits specify the direction of approach, which can yield different values.
principles.application: Essential for piecewise functions, absolute value functions, and functions with jumps.
principles.analogy: Like approaching a border crossing from different countries—you may encounter different rules depending on your direction of travel.

principles.statement: $\lim_{x \to c} f(x)$ exists if and only if $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)$.
principles.application: Use one-sided limits to determine if a two-sided limit exists.
principles.analogy: Like two people walking toward the same meeting point from opposite directions—they must arrive at the same location for the meeting to succeed.

sections.introduction: Proper notation is essential for clearly communicating which type of limit we are evaluating. The superscript signs indicate the direction of approach.

classifications.behavior: Considers only values of $x$ that are less than $c$

examples.explanation: $\lim_{x \to 2^-} f(x)$ examines behavior as $x$ approaches 2 from values like 1.9, 1.99, 1.999...

image.alt: Arrow approaching point from left side
image.caption: Figure 3: Left-hand limit approaches from the negative direction.

classifications.behavior: Considers only values of $x$ that are greater than $c$

examples.explanation: $\lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x)$ examines behavior as $x$ approaches 2 from values like 2.1, 2.01, 2.001...

image.alt: Arrow approaching point from right side
image.caption: Figure 4: Right-hand limit approaches from the positive direction.

classifications.behavior: Exists only if both one-sided limits exist and are equal

image.alt: Arrows approaching point from both sides
image.caption: Figure 5: Two-sided limit requires both sides to converge to the same value.

sections.introduction: Graphs provide an intuitive way to evaluate one-sided limits by tracing the function from the appropriate direction.

process_flow.description: Locate $x = c$ on the horizontal axis.
process_flow.result: Vertical reference line at the target value.

image.alt: Graph with vertical line at target x-value
image.caption: Step 1: Mark the target $x$-value $c$.

process_flow.description: For left-hand limit, start from the left side. For right-hand limit, start from the right side.

image.alt: Arrow showing direction of approach
image.caption: Step 2: Select left or right approach direction.

process_flow.description: Follow the graph toward $x = c$ from the chosen direction.

image.alt: Path tracing along the curve toward the point
image.caption: Step 3: Trace the function toward $x = c$.

process_flow.description: Note the $y$-value that the function approaches.

image.alt: Final y-value highlighted on graph
image.caption: Step 4: Record the $y$-value approached.

worked_examples.title: Reading One-Sided Limits from a Graph
worked_examples.problem: Given the graph in Figure 6, evaluate $\lim_{x \to 3^-} f(x)$, $\lim_{x \to 3^+} f(x)$, and $\lim_{x \to 3} f(x)$.

step_by_step.explanation: Trace the graph from the left side toward $x = 3$. The function approaches $y = 2$.
Trace the graph from the right side toward $x = 3$. The function approaches $y = 4$.
Compare the one-sided limits. Since $2 \neq 4$, the two-sided limit does not exist.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Two-sided limit exists only when one-sided limits are equal.

image.alt: Graph showing jump discontinuity at x=3
image.caption: Figure 6: Jump discontinuity at $x = 3$ with different one-sided limits.

sections.introduction: For piecewise functions and functions with absolute values, algebraic evaluation requires selecting the correct function piece based on the direction of approach.

key_concept.definition: When evaluating one-sided limits algebraically, use the function definition that applies to the direction of approach ($x < c$ for left-hand, $x > c$ for right-hand).
key_concept.context: This is especially important for piecewise functions where different formulas apply on different intervals.

worked_examples.title: One-Sided Limits of a Piecewise Function
worked_examples.problem: Given $f(x) = \begin{cases} x + 1 & x < 2 \\ 3x - 1 & x \geq 2 \end{cases}$, evaluate $\lim_{x \to 2^-} f(x)$, $\lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x)$, and $\lim_{x \to 2} f(x)$.

step_by_step.explanation: For $x \to 2^-$, we have $x < 2$, so use $f(x) = x + 1$.
For $x \to 2^+$, we have $x > 2$, so use $f(x) = 3x - 1$.
Compare one-sided limits: $3 \neq 5$.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Piecewise functions require selecting the correct piece based on approach direction.

image.alt: Graph of piecewise function showing different limits at boundary
image.caption: Figure 7: Piecewise function with different one-sided limits at $x = 2$.

worked_examples.title: One-Sided Limits with Absolute Value

step_by_step.explanation: $|x| = \begin{cases} -x & x < 0 \\ x & x \geq 0 \end{cases}$
For $x \to 0^-$, we have $x < 0$, so $|x| = -x$.
For $x \to 0^+$, we have $x > 0$, so $|x| = x$.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Absolute value functions require case analysis based on the sign of $x$.

image.alt: Graph of |x|/x showing sign function behavior
image.caption: Figure 8: The sign function $\frac{|x|}{x}$ has different one-sided limits at $x = 0$.

worked_examples.title: One-Sided Limits with Radicals

step_by_step.explanation: The expression $\sqrt{4 - x}$ requires $4 - x \geq 0$, so $x \leq 4$.
For $x \to 4^-$, we have $x < 4$, so $4 - x > 0$ (valid).
For $x \to 4^+$, we have $x > 4$, so $4 - x < 0$ (undefined in reals).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Radical functions may have one-sided limits only when the domain is restricted.

image.alt: Graph of sqrt(4-x) showing domain ends at x=4
image.caption: Figure 9: The function $\sqrt{4 - x}$ is only defined for $x \leq 4$.

sections.section_title: 1.7.5 Relationship Between One-Sided and Two-Sided Limits
sections.introduction: Understanding the precise relationship between one-sided and two-sided limits is fundamental to limit theory and continuity analysis.

image.alt: Flowchart showing relationship between one-sided and two-sided limits
image.caption: Figure 10: Decision tree for determining two-sided limit existence from one-sided limits.

principles.statement: $\lim_{x \to c} f(x) = L$ if and only if $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) = L$ and $\lim_{x \to c^+} f(x) = L$.
principles.application: Use to prove two-sided limits exist or don't exist.
principles.analogy: Like a bridge that must connect from both sides to be complete.

principles.statement: If $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x) \neq \lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)$, then $\lim_{x \to c} f(x)$ does not exist.
principles.application: Quick test for limit non-existence at jump discontinuities.
principles.analogy: Like two roads that don't meet at an intersection—there's no single destination.

principles.statement: One-sided limits can exist even when the two-sided limit does not.
principles.application: Common at jump discontinuities and endpoints of domains.
principles.analogy: Like having a view from one side of a canyon but not from both sides meeting.

characteristics: Function may or may not be continuous

image.alt: Parabola showing equal limits from both sides
image.caption: Figure 11: Both sides approach the same value; two-sided limit exists.

examples.explanation: Step function at the jump point.

image.alt: Step function showing different limits
image.caption: Figure 12: Different one-sided limits; two-sided limit does not exist.

classifications.type: Case 3: One One-Sided Limit Does Not Exist

image.alt: Square root function at domain endpoint
image.caption: Figure 13: One side outside domain; two-sided limit does not exist.

image.alt: Function with vertical asymptote
image.caption: Figure 14: Both sides approach infinity; infinite limit.

sections.introduction: While less common, one-sided notation can also apply to limits at infinity, particularly when analyzing behavior from positive or negative directions.

key_concept.definition: $\lim_{x \to \infty} f(x)$ examines behavior as $x$ grows positively without bound. $\lim_{x \to -\infty} f(x)$ examines behavior as $x$ grows negatively without bound.
key_concept.context: These are technically one-sided limits at infinity, though the superscript notation is not typically used.

worked_examples.title: Limits at Positive and Negative Infinity

step_by_step.explanation: As $x$ grows large positively, $\frac{1}{x}$ approaches 0 from above.
As $x$ grows large negatively, $\frac{1}{x}$ approaches 0 from below.
Both limits equal 0, but approach from different directions.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Limits at infinity describe end behavior in positive and negative directions.

image.alt: Graph of 1/x showing behavior at positive and negative infinity
image.caption: Figure 15: The function $\frac{1}{x}$ approaches 0 from both directions at infinity.

sections.section_title: 1.7.8 Common Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Understanding common mistakes in one-sided limit evaluation helps prevent errors and builds stronger conceptual understanding.

classifications.behavior: Remember: minus = left side of number line, plus = right side

examples.explanation: Writing $\lim_{x \to 2^+}$ when meaning approach from left.

image.alt: Warning about notation confusion
image.caption: Figure 19: Remember: $c^-$ is left, $c^+$ is right.

classifications.behavior: Always check both one-sided limits before concluding two-sided limit exists

sections.introduction: Apply your understanding of one-sided and two-sided limits to these practice problems.

worked_examples.title: Comprehensive One-Sided Limit Problem
worked_examples.problem: Given $f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 3 & x < 1 \\ 5 & x = 1 \\ -x + 6 & x > 1 \end{cases}$, evaluate all three limits at $x = 1$ and determine continuity.

step_by_step.explanation: For $x \to 1^-$, use $f(x) = 2x + 3$.
For $x \to 1^+$, use $f(x) = -x + 6$.
Since both one-sided limits equal 5, the two-sided limit exists.
Compare limit to function value: $f(1) = 5 = \lim_{x \to 1} f(x)$.

worked_examples.final_answer: $\lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = 5$, $\lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = 5$, $\lim_{x \to 1} f(x) = 5$; $f$ is continuous at $x = 1$
worked_examples.concept_applied: When one-sided limits agree and equal the function value, the function is continuous.

image.alt: Graph of piecewise function continuous at x=1
image.caption: Figure 24: This piecewise function is continuous at $x = 1$ because all limits agree with $f(1)$.

worked_examples.title: Absolute Value Limit Problem

step_by_step.explanation: $|x - 3| = \begin{cases} -(x - 3) & x < 3 \\ x - 3 & x \geq 3 \end{cases}$
For $x \to 3^-$, we have $x < 3$, so $|x - 3| = -(x - 3)$.
For $x \to 3^+$, we have $x > 3$, so $|x - 3| = x - 3$.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Absolute value expressions create different one-sided limits at the critical point.

summary: Section 1.7 explored one-sided and two-sided limits in detail. We learned that left-hand limits $\lim_{x \to c^-} f(x)$ approach from values less than $c$, while right-hand limits $\lim_{x \to c^+} f(x)$ approach from values greater than $c$. The fundamental theorem states that a two-sided limit $\lim_{x \to c} f(x)$ exists if and only if both one-sided limits exist and are equal. We practiced evaluating one-sided limits graphically by tracing from the appropriate direction, and algebraically by selecting the correct function piece for piecewise functions and analyzing absolute value cases. We identified four cases: (1) both one-sided limits equal (two-sided exists), (2) one-sided limits differ (two-sided DNE), (3) one side undefined (two-sided DNE), and (4) both sides infinite (infinite limit). Applications include piecewise-defined real functions, physics problems with direction-dependent behavior, and domain endpoints. Common pitfalls include confusing left/right notation, assuming two-sided limits always exist, using the wrong piece in piecewise functions, ignoring domain restrictions, and confusing limit values with function values. Mastery of one-sided limits is essential for analyzing continuity, especially at boundary points and discontinuities.
